all_paragraphs: There are many ways to learn data science. There are many courses, boot camps, online tutorials, and many more. I have seen many people with data science certifications unable to find a job. The problem is, most of the courses or boot camps don’t teach you the skills required to get a job. The best way to become employable is by getting practical experience. The most effective way to acquire skills that will get you hired is by working on projects.

The data science teams work on solving many business problems. The approach for each one of them will be very different. Yet, the core skills required to solve a problem don’t change much. The majority of real-life data science problems belong to one of the below categories.

In this article, I am going to share some problems, approaches to solving them, and reference scripts. To help you learn to solve almost any data science problem. Also, this will help you to acquire the skills that will get you a job.

Regression problems are often underestimated and not given due importance. Some people even try to learn fancy algorithms without learning the basics. You can get hired if you fail to explain a topic in deep learning. But, if you fail to explain a regression algorithm that’s enough to not hire you.

In regression problems, a target variable is a continuous number. The value of the target variable depends on the independent variables. This is one of the most common data science problems. The regression problems can be further classified into linear and non-linear.

A simple example of a linear regression algorithm is predicting the housing price. There are many factors influencing a housing price. All those factors that influence housing prices are independent variables. The housing price attribute is the dependent/target variable. Classification problems are another popular category of machine learning algorithms. It is part of supervised learning. The output variable here is categorical. When the output variable takes one of the two possible values then it is a binary classification. For example, Customer churn or Not, Spam email or Not, and so on. When the output variable has more than 2 possible outcomes then it is a multiclass classification.

The approach to solving a classification problem is very similar to that of the regression problem. The main difference would be in the model evaluations. The techniques and methods commonly used for evaluation in a classification problem are,

The clustering algorithm is an unsupervised learning algorithm. There is no label for model training. We look for patterns present in the dataset to group them into different clusters.
Solving a clustering problem is different from solving a supervised learning problem. The steps involved are,
Like any supervised learning problem, we start with data exploration. The difference is we focus more on the visual analysis. The goal here is to understand if there are any clear clusters.

The next step is to identify the right set of algorithms. The choice of the algorithm would depend on the problem itself. In most cases, we would create clusters where one item belongs to only one cluster. Sometimes we need to allow items to belong to more than one cluster. In the first case, we use algorithms such as K-Mean and Hierarchical Clustering. For the latter, we use Fuzzy Clustering. Customer profiling is a typical example of fuzzy clustering. It would be normal for customers to exhibit many characteristics. Here it is fair to allow them to be part of multiple clusters with a probability.
3. The ideal number of clusters
It is critical to identify the ideal number of clusters. There are techniques and methods to identify the best number of clusters. The technique depends on the algorithm.

A clustering problem is not considered solved after identifying the clusters. It is not enough to show the business the different clusters. It requires further analysis to prove the clusters are correct. Visual analysis plays a key role here. It is easy to pick insights from visual data.

There are many case studies on the recommendation problems. There has been a huge value capitalized from the recommendation systems. They are increasingly adopted across industries. The recommendation systems are usually built using Collaborative filtering and Content-based filtering methods.

In the case of collaborative filtering, we have user-based or item-based similarities. For example, to produce a recommendation for user ‘A’. First, we need to find users who are similar to user ‘A’. Then the items popular among similar users are used in case of user-based recommendations. In an item-based method, all similar items are grouped together. For example, their likelihood of being sold together. When a user purchases one item the other similar items from the group are recommended.

In the case of content-based filtering, the descriptions about the products and the users are used for recommendations. For example, the details of the products and the interests of the users are matched to produce the best recommendation for the users. Dating platforms are a perfect place for content-based recommendations.

There is so much data on social media platforms and other public domains. There is a lot of value in these unstructured data.
